awd_titl_txt: Ultra high boiling performance on nano/microstructured surfaces through electrodeposition of copper and graphene
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1335927
PI: Kandlikar 

The proposed project Ultra High Pool Boiling Performance on Novel Microstructures through Pulsed Electrodeposition of Graphene/Carbon Nanotubes and their Copper Composites? strives to gain a fundamental understanding of the boiling mechanism over enhanced microstructured surfaces with nanocoatings at preferred locations. A new model that incorporates the role of microconvection in enhancing the boiling heat transfer will be developed and validated by using advanced visualization and measurement techniques employing high speed imaging (up to 25,000 fps), and microthermocouples of 5 - 13 µm dimensions. The model will be further validated through COMSOL Multiphysics® numerical simulation and pool boiling experiments over individually designed microsctruture features with nanocoatings applied over preferred regions. The fundamental insight gained through the localized bubble/liquid motion and the associated heat transfer will provide new avenues in enhancing and modeling the pool boiling heat transfer and critical heat flux (CHF). Some of the recent advances in the field of electrochemistry will be utilized in developing multi-porous graphene-based structures that are highly conductive and can provide controlled morphological features for heat transfer and CHF enhancement.

The pool boiling constitutes an extremely important mode of heat transfer that is applied in a number of critical technologies including power generation (nuclear, fossil fuel, and alternative energy source based), electronics cooling, petrochemical and process industries, and air-conditioning and refrigeration applications. Heat transfer performance improvements in the boiling process are generally aimed at: (i) a reduction in the wall superheat, and (ii) an increase in the maximum heat transfer rate, identified as the critical heat flux. The proposed project provides a new pathway to address both of these performance improvement parameters. The new approach and the modeling proposed in this project will provide a new pathway in improving energy efficiencies of devices utilizing the boiling process. This is in particular of great significance for utilizing alternative thermal energy sources, since the available temperature differences are generally low and are of critical importance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In this work, the PI and his team developed multiscale surfaces for enhanced boiling heat transfer performance.

  • The microscale surfaces comprised of open microchannels, sintered microchannels, electrodeposited microchannels, nucleating regions with feeder channels, etc. These configurations were able to effectively modulate the two-phase flow structure paving the pathway for advanced thermal management solutions in electronics cooling.
  • An electrochemical cell was devised to produce graphene through a simple two-step electrodeposition process. This approach is highly scalable and is attractive to materials, heat transfer and electronics industry where cost-effective manufacturing of graphene is desired.
  • Advanced material characterization techniques (electron microscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetry, etc.) were employed to unravel the structure-property relationships.
  • The micro and nanoscale coatings developed using graphene and other chemical coatings resulted in unprecedented heat transfer performance enhancements and new boiling heat transfer mechanisms. The fundamental heat transfer processes governing the enhancement were explained.

The results obtained through the award are relevant and can be readily adopted in many applications including electronics cooling, refrigeration systems, nuclear systems, etc. The fundamental studies conducted here can be exploited in the next generation devices to achieve energy-efficient strategies in thermal and material science engineering disciplines. The fundamental results have been disseminated to the community through journal articles, conference proceedings, graduate seminar talks, etc.

The outreach activities undertaken through this award include:

-   E3 fair: a science and technology fair for middle school students in the Rochester area.

-   Beyond 9.8: an initiative for 6th grade students to work in research labs at Rochester Institute of Technology.

-   Upstate Loius Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ULSAMP)

-   Women in Engineering (WE) Program at RIT: an initiative aimed at inspiring young women to pursue careers engineering

-   IMAGINE RIT: Innovation and creativity fair in the Greater Rochester area. 

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2017
Modified by: Satish G Kandlikar

por.por_txt_cntn:
In this work, the PI and his team developed multiscale surfaces for enhanced boiling heat transfer performance.

The microscale surfaces comprised of open microchannels, sintered microchannels, electrodeposited microchannels, nucleating regions with feeder channels, etc. These configurations were able to effectively modulate the two-phase flow structure paving the pathway for advanced thermal management solutions in electronics cooling. 
An electrochemical cell was devised to produce graphene through a simple two-step electrodeposition process. This approach is highly scalable and is attractive to materials, heat transfer and electronics industry where cost-effective manufacturing of graphene is desired.
Advanced material characterization techniques (electron microscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetry, etc.) were employed to unravel the structure-property relationships. 
The micro and nanoscale coatings developed using graphene and other chemical coatings resulted in unprecedented heat transfer performance enhancements and new boiling heat transfer mechanisms. The fundamental heat transfer processes governing the enhancement were explained. 


The results obtained through the award are relevant and can be readily adopted in many applications including electronics cooling, refrigeration systems, nuclear systems, etc. The fundamental studies conducted here can be exploited in the next generation devices to achieve energy-efficient strategies in thermal and material science engineering disciplines. The fundamental results have been disseminated to the community through journal articles, conference proceedings, graduate seminar talks, etc.

The outreach activities undertaken through this award include:

-   E3 fair: a science and technology fair for middle school students in the Rochester area.

-   Beyond 9.8: an initiative for 6th grade students to work in research labs at Rochester Institute of Technology.

-   Upstate Loius Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ULSAMP)

-   Women in Engineering (WE) Program at RIT: an initiative aimed at inspiring young women to pursue careers engineering

-   IMAGINE RIT: Innovation and creativity fair in the Greater Rochester area.
